caption: Singer Celine Dion died in a plane crash in November 2019.

result.explanation: The image shows Celine Dion, a singer, who is still alive.  The caption states she died in a plane crash in November 2019, which is factually incorrect.

candidates.title: No, Celine Dion Didn't Die in a Plane Crash
candidates.content:
Claim:
Singer Celine Dion died in a plane crash in November 2019.
Rating:
False
About this rating
In November 2019, a video supposedly featuring a CNN news report about the death of singer Celine Dion was widely circulated on social media:
This is not a genuine CNN news report, and Dion did not perish in a plane crash.
This video is not hosted on CNN.com. Rather, it was posted on websites such as online.newstrends2k18.info and https://worldnews.hytactv.info. These are not a credible sources for news. In fact, these websites don't appear to have a functioning homepage and seem to have been set up simply to host this fraudulent news report.
Viewers who watched this video will notice that the two news anchors never actually say Celine Dion's name. Rather, they say "we have some terribly sad news to report this morning, heartbreaking, and devastating" before cutting away to a still image of the singer. That's because the first few seconds of this video come from a news report about the death of a different celebrity: chef Anthony Bourdain.
Here's the original news report:
Whoever created the fraudulent video took the first few seconds from CNN's report on Bourdain's death, changed the chyron to read about Dion, and then cut the footage short and replaced it with an image of the singer.
We should also note that this fake video started circulating on or prior to Nov. 3, 2019. Since then, Dion has held concerts in Milwaukee and Detroit, something that would be difficult to do after dying in a plane crash:
candidates.description: The singer was killed (again) by a death hoax.

result.explanation: The news caption is explicitly stated as false in the provided evidence. Source 1, from Snopes, directly addresses the claim that Celine Dion died in a plane crash in November 2019, rating it as false.  The source details how the claim originated from a fabricated video and provides evidence that Celine Dion was still performing concerts at the time.
result.supporting_points: Source 1: Snopes fact-check explicitly states the claim is false.  The explanation shows how the claim was based on a manipulated video and that Dion performed concerts after the supposed date of death.

final_result.explanation: The provided image shows Celine Dion, a singer, appearing healthy and alive during a performance. This directly contradicts the caption's claim that she died in a plane crash in November 2019. The internal check identifies this discrepancy with high confidence (confidence_score: 10).  The external check corroborates this finding using a Snopes fact-check, which definitively labels the claim as false (confidence_score: 10). Snopes provides evidence demonstrating that the death rumor stemmed from a fabricated video and that Celine Dion continued performing concerts after the purported date of death.  There is complete agreement between the internal and external validation methods.  The visual evidence, showing a vibrant and active Celine Dion, is consistent with the factual information from the external source. No inconsistencies or ambiguities were detected during either validation step.  The high confidence scores from both checks, combined with the strong visual evidence and the lack of any contradictory information, lead to the conclusion that the caption is entirely out of context and factually inaccurate. The image does not depict a person who has passed away; it shows a living person. The image is not tampered or miscontextualized.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external checks strongly indicate that the caption is out of context. The image shows Celine Dion alive, while the caption falsely claims her death in a plane crash.  Snopes fact-check confirms the falsity of the death claim.
